meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how 直 can also mean <kanji>fix</kanji>? Well, this word uses that meaning, so it's <vocabulary>to fix</vocabulary>. This is when you're fixing something, as in doing the actual physical action of fixing.

This is a strange one, but only at first glance. You <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>house</kanji>. You'd think this would mean something like "building a house" or "construction" or something. Instead, it means writer. Think of it this way: A <vocabulary>writer</vocabulary> <kanji>makes</kanji> (writes and creates works) in their <kanji>home</kanji>. Writers don't make their word magic in a corporate office!

作家 is generally used to refer to someone who writes professionally as an occupation, especially in the field of literature. It can also be used more broadly to refer to a creator who produces individual works of art or craft.

Remember how 手 can mean a "doer"? Now, what do you think your <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji> might be? It’s someone who shares the same activities or tasks with you. This person could be your <vocabulary>partner</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>companion</vocabulary>, or even an <vocabulary>opponent</vocabulary> in certain situations.
The <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>sunshine</kanji> thing up in the sky... what is it called? Oh, that's right. It's the <vocabulary>sun</vocabulary>.
You know that 好き is "like." Although 好き is kind of like a verb already, this is definitely a verb. It can be <vocabulary>to be fond of</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to like</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>feeling</kanji>s you <kanji>contemplate</kanji> about a subject are your <vocabulary>impressions</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>thoughts</vocabulary> on it.

感想 is all about what you think or feel after experiencing something, like after reading a book, watching a movie, or going to an event.

This one's kinda tricky. You learned 様 is a "formal name ender," but it can also mean "manner," as in the manner you do something in. So if you've got multiple manners, you've got lots of <vocabulary>various</vocabulary> ways of doing things!

The <kanji>luck</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> wasn't actually too lucky. This is <vocabulary>Fukushima</vocabulary> where the nuclear meltdown happened after the 2011 earthquake. So, when you think of "luck island" this is where you should think.
What is a <kanji>skill</kanji>? It's something you can do, and do quite well. It is a <vocabulary>technique</vocabulary> that you can make happen with ease.

Your <kanji>skill</kanji> and <kanji>ability</kanji> are kind of similar things. That's why this word means either or. Your skill ability is your <vocabulary>skill</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ability</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>special</kanji> <kanji>skill</kanji> is your <vocabulary>specialty</vocabulary>. So, what is your 特技?

You need <kanji>art</kanji> <kanji>technique</kanji>s to make <vocabulary>art</vocabulary>. Without art techniques, <vocabulary>the arts</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fine art</vocabulary> simply wouldn’t exist.
When you create <kanji>beauty</kanji> with your <kanji>technique</kanji>s, that’s <vocabulary>fine art</vocabulary>, or simply <vocabulary>art</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>buddha</kanji> <kanji>teach</kanji>ings are what you have to learn when you're studying <vocabulary>Buddhism</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>large</kanji> <kanji>Buddha</kanji> doesn't make sense if you don't know the context. There are giant statues of Buddha, and these are called Daibutsu, making this word translate to the <vocabulary>Great Buddha</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Giant Buddha Statue</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>believe</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to believe</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>believe</kanji> in your <kanji>self</kanji> you have plenty of <vocabulary>confidence</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>self confidence</vocabulary>). This is a good thing to have!

If you <kanji>believe</kanji> in the <kanji>number</kanji>s, there will be no traffic because the <vocabulary>traffic light</vocabulary> will be functioning properly. Traffic lights are based all off of traffic data and numbers. You just have to believe and hope it all works out in terms of these traffic lights.

What you <kanji>believe</kanji> in your <kanji>heart</kanji>, and not in your head, is your <vocabulary>faith</vocabulary>. This is something that doesn't follow logic, it's all heart belief, it's all <vocabulary>faith</vocabulary>.

When someone <kanji>believes</kanji> in your <kanji>task</kanji>, it means they have a lot of <vocabulary>trust</vocabulary> in what you do. You've clearly gained a great deal of <vocabulary>credibility</vocabulary> through your previous tasks.

信用 refers to the trust one party places in another's integrity and ability to fulfill obligations. It's often used to describe reliability in actions, faithfulness in relationships, or creditworthiness in financial transactions.

When you can't (<kanji>not</kanji>) <kanji>believe</kanji> in someone, it's because you <vocabulary>distrust</vocabulary> them. Maybe someone <vocabulary>discredit</vocabulary>ed them and now you <vocabulary>mistrust</vocabulary> everything they say.

You gotta <kanji>believe</kanji> it will <kanji>return</kanji>. What are you believing in returning? The <vocabulary>reply</vocabulary>. You made a request for something (come up with something you want really bad but have to ask for). Now you wait for the reply.
That <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>courage</kanji> is <vocabulary>courage</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>district</kanji> isn't our solar system or something like that. We're talking about a specific portion of earth, and naming it as a district. So, what is this patch of earth? It's a <vocabulary>district</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>area</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>zone</vocabulary>.
If you're moving towards (に) <kanji>simple</kanji>, you're saying <vocabulary>simply</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>merely</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>only</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>simple</kanji> bits of <kanji>language</kanji> are the individual <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>s. If you think about it, this is true. First of all, there are a ton of them. Second, they're tiny. They're just little bits of language and the "word" for these little bits is <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>.

So what’s the difference between this and 言葉? Well, 言葉 can cover any meaningful set of words – anything from words, sentences and paragraphs, to whole texts and even languages. 単語, on the other hand, is a subset of 言葉 that specifically refers to single, distinct words.
The <kanji>director</kanji> who is <kanji>above</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>boss</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>superior</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is more the "strange" meaning though, not the "change" one. As in, you 変な猫！
A <kanji>strange</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is <vocabulary>an eccentric</vocabulary>. They are also an <vocabulary>oddball</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Change</kanji> and <kanji>change</kanji> equals even more <vocabulary>change</vocabulary>.

変化 generally refers to a natural or spontaneous change, like changes from growth or aging, alterations in weather conditions, or shifts in one's emotions.

A <kanji>strange</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji> is one that doesn't seem right. It's an <vocabulary>unnatural death</vocabulary>, and probably an <vocabulary>accidental death</vocabulary> (ie wasn't caused by natural causes).

A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>change</kanji> is a really <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary> thing. And people don't like change, either, making it a <vocabulary>terrible</vocabulary> event. 

Also, in more recent history this has come to mean <vocabulary>very</vocabulary> as well.

An <kanji>occurrence</kanji> that causes <kanji>change</kanji> somehow can also be called an <vocabulary>incident</vocabulary>. 

事変 is a formal word for big, unexpected incidents that are disruptive and chaotic. This can involve natural disasters, sudden riots, or other large-scale disturbances that need military intervention. It can also refer to unannounced warfare.

You'll most likely see this word used in names for historical events, like the Manshuu Jihen (満州事変), or the Manchurian Incident. The 変 kanji suggests "change," so you know 事変 is only used for historical incidents big enough to make things change!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return home</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to return home</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to return</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to go home</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You've seen 夏休み and 冬休み. If that isn't enough, you can see that this is a <kanji>spring</kanji> <kanji>rest</kanji> of some kind. That would be a <vocabulary>spring break</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>spring vacation</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Previous</kanji> from <kanji>now</kanji> are the times around now. They're <vocabulary>these days</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>nowadays</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>yesterday</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is <vocabulary>yesterday</vocabulary>. What a blast from the past!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This can also mean <vocabulary>lunch</vocabulary>, especially when used with the honorific prefix お, as in お昼.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word is made of <kanji>now</kanji> and <kanji>night</kanji> with the hiragana は at the end. The は here is pronounced as わ (the old pronunciation). When you say "now night!" you're really saying <vocabulary>good evening</vocabulary>.

Just keep in mind that writing 今晩は is pretty old school. These days it's almost always written as こんばんは.
<kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>night</kanji> is simply <vocabulary>every night</vocabulary>. What do you do every night?

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>clear up</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to clear up</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>to become sunny</vocabulary> as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of <kanji>poison</kanji>, meaning you have <vocabulary>poisoning</vocabulary>.

Things that <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>poison</kanji> are <vocabulary>toxic</vocabulary>. 

有毒 is a relatively formal word generally used to describe toxic materials or substances. It can also be used for formal classifications like 有毒植物 (<vocabulary>poisonous</vocabulary> plants) or 有毒動物 (poisonous and venomous animals).
If you <kanji>eat</kanji> and find yourself in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of <kanji>poison</kanji>, you've probably got <vocabulary>food poisoning</vocabulary>. No fun when you get this :(
<kanji>Poison</kanji> Gas is a nasty thing. It is <vocabulary>poison gas</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>way</kanji> <kanji>method</kanji> or the <kanji>method</kanji> <kanji>way</kanji> is the <vocabulary>method</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>way</vocabulary>. This is a good word for talking about how to do something. What's the 方法? Well, first you...

The <kanji>method</kanji> of <kanji>writing</kanji> is how you write. You can have vocabulary words, but you have to be able to put them together using some kind of method. This method happens to be <vocabulary>grammar</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>law</kanji> is something that's against the law. It's <vocabulary>illegal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unlawful</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cry</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>shallow</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>shallow</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Meow!
A <kanji>child</kanji> <kanji>cat</kanji> is an adorable <vocabulary>kitten</vocabulary>. D'awww!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>account</kanji> of a <kanji>generation</kanji>... this covers a whole generation, and considering how long Japanese people live, this account totals a whole <vocabulary>century</vocabulary>.

What does the <kanji>narrative</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> have coming <kanji>after</kanji> it? Well, the way we've counted years for the past couple of millenia has a specific narrative at its origin, and everything that comes after it is the <vocabulary>Common Era</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>AD</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>anno Domini</vocabulary>.

Just in case you don't know what narrative we're talking about: it's the narrative of Jesus's birth, which is the year that we say the Common Era started.
The <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>language</kanji> is the language you're reading right here and now. This is the <vocabulary>English language</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>English</vocabulary>.

<kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>ing and <kanji>talk</kanji>ing with each other. This is <vocabulary>English Conversation</vocabulary>. This is used a lot when talking about "speaking in English" for studying English and whatnot.
<kanji>England</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is <vocabulary>English Writing</vocabulary> (or if you want to be fancy, <vocabulary>English Composition</vocabulary>).

The <kanji>England</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is where England is. This word can refer to <vocabulary>Britain</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>United Kingdom</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>England</vocabulary>!

Note that イギリス is more common for "England" - but, since this is a kanji learning website you should learn this word.

This is seen on things like dictionaries. When you have an <kanji>English</kanji> and <kanji>Japanese</kanji> (style) dictionary, for example. You'll see it the other way around too, but this particular one is <vocabulary>English Japanese</vocabulary>.

A thing that gives you <kanji>time</kanji> <kanji>measurement</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>watch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>clock</vocabulary>. Most people have these in their phones instead of on their wrists now.
When you <kanji>join</kanji> all your <kanji>measure</kanji>ments together you have yourself a <vocabulary>total</vocabulary>.

You need <kanji>measurement</kanji>s and <kanji>image</kanji>s to make a <vocabulary>plan</vocabulary>. You can't follow a plan without measurements and images to refer to, right? Any good plan has measurements and drawings.

When you <kanji>measure</kanji> and then <kanji>calculate</kanji> something, you are making a <vocabulary>calculation</vocabulary>. For example, you measure the length of a frog, then you calculate how many frogs you'd need to reach the moon. What is that? A calculation, of course.
An <kanji>army</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is someone in the army. What are those people called? They're <vocabulary>soldier</vocabulary>s.
The <kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>army</kanji> are the branch of the military that has boats and does ocean/sea things. What's that? The <vocabulary>navy</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also refers to <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary>, because you gotta eat cooked rice with every meal, so it's basically synonymous with "meal" itself.

This word has a slightly gruff feel to it so it's used mostly in informal situations.

The ご just makes this word more polite and fancy — two important qualities when it comes to food. This has the same meaning as the kanji (<kanji>meal</kanji>), making it <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>, but it can also just mean <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary>. So, "Come eat your ご飯" can mean either "come eat your rice" or "come eat your meal" — or both, since most Japanese meals come with rice anyway.

You know how 器用 means "dextrous" and "skillful"? Well, this is when you're <kanji>not</kanji> those things. When you're not dextrous, you're <vocabulary>clumsy</vocabulary> and when you're not skillful you're <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary>.
The noun form of <kanji>request</kanji> (don't be tricked by the い on the end, it's not an adjective). So, request goes to <vocabulary>a request</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Drink</kanji>ing <kanji>as much as you want</kanji> is nice and all, but don't get sick. When you see this word, you know you're at an <vocabulary>all you can drink</vocabulary> place. Tip: Usually there's a time limit, so drink up!
When you <kanji>eat</kanji> <kanji>as much as you want</kanji>, you are getting an <vocabulary>all you can eat</vocabulary> deal.
When you <kanji>kill</kanji> a <kanji>person</kanji> that's <vocabulary>murder</vocabulary>.
You've hopefully seen 殺人 (murder) from level 13. So, <kanji>someone</kanji> who does <kanji>murder</kanji> is what? A <vocabulary>murderer</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>finger</kanji> <kanji>ring</kanji> is the kind of <vocabulary>ring</vocabulary> you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context.

A <kanji>ring</kanji> of gum (ゴム) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a <vocabulary>rubber band</vocabulary>.
Hopefully you've seen 暗記 before now. It means "memorization." So, turn that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to memorize</vocabulary>.
You've hopefully seen 練習, which means "practice." So, if you make it into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to practice</vocabulary>.

You know 変 means "change," but it can also mean "strange." So a <kanji>strange</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is an incident that is unlikely. In other words, an <vocabulary>unexpected incident</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>unusual incident</vocabulary>.

変事 is a formal word used to describe sudden and unusual occurrences that disrupt normal conditions, such as natural disasters, emergencies, or crises. You won't see this word often, but may still come across it in formal writing.

With 変事, think of how the 変 comes first to emphasize the strangeness of the incident.

You're making things in two different places be exactly the <kanji>same</kanji> for <kanji>a period of time</kanji>. You're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of a process called <vocabulary>syncing</vocabulary>. You can see 同期中 a lot in computery contexts, or if you change your device language to Japanese. (Not that I recommend that...)
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You <kanji>compare</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji>s, trying to figure out in which way they're <vocabulary>being proportional</vocabulary>. You know these examples you're comparing are in <vocabulary>proportion</vocabulary> to one another, you just need to figure out how. 

Use 比例 when talking about how one thing changes in proportion to another. Like the price of a good in proportion to its supply and demand, for instance. Check out our common word combinations and context sentences for some examples!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>solve</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be solved</vocabulary>. In a similar vein, this can also mean <vocabulary>to be cleared</vocabulary>, like with misunderstandings or tension in a room.

解ける is an intransitive verb, so it doesn't take a direct object. In other words, you use it to say something is solved or gets solved. You can remember this because you don't <reading>care</reading> (ける) enough to solve things yourself, you just let things get solved on their own.

Something with a <kanji>beauty</kanji> <kanji>taste</kanji> is something that is really <vocabulary>tasty</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>delicious</vocabulary>. Mmmm, yum!

While 美味しい mostly describes tasty food, you may also occasionally see it being used for a sweet deal or situation that benefits you.

When you've <kanji>finish</kanji>ed <kanji>solv</kanji>ing something, you've come to a point of <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary>. 

了解 is often used to show your understanding of information or instructions that have been communicated to you, similar to "<vocabulary>Got it</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>Understood</vocabulary>." It can also be used to show agreement, approval, or consent, since those things naturally depend on mutual understanding too.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pay</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pay</vocabulary>.

This word also means <vocabulary>to brush off</vocabulary>, like when you brush dirt or dust off of something.

The kanji is <kanji>change</kanji>, and this verb is <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary>. If you change one thing for another thing, you are going <vocabulary>to change</vocabulary> it, after all. This word refers to changing one thing for a similar thing.

変える and 代える sound the same and are sometimes used in similar contexts, but are different in nuance. 変える refers to the act of making something different, and involves altering the nature or state of something. For example, changing the layout of a room or changing one's perspective on an issue. 代える means to substitute or exchange one thing for another that is expected to fulfill the same role, use or purpose, such as replacing a worker with a substitute.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Four</kanji> <kanji>small animal</kanji>s is <vocabulary>four small animals</vocabulary>. Use this to count four dogs, or cats, or whatever else.

With the <kanji>height</kanji> of my <kanji>husband</kanji>, he's very <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>. Try to push him over. Impossible. He's so tall and <vocabulary>sturdy</vocabulary> due to his height.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word is usually used for clothing <vocabulary>height</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>length</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>stubborn</kanji> <kanji>height</kanji> is a shorter, stockier height. It makes a person especially <vocabulary>solid</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>stout</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>see</kanji> someone doubting you and <kanji>return</kanji> something successful instead, that is <vocabulary>to show someone what one can do</vocabulary> or more simply <vocabulary>to show someone</vocabulary>. In other words, you show someone who doubted you or treated you unfairly what you’re really capable of.

There are a couple of other meanings, too. It can mean <vocabulary>to look back over something</vocabulary>, like the answers to your kanji test you want to double check, and sometimes <vocabulary>to return someone’s stare</vocabulary>. You can see how all of these meanings relate to the kanji, right?

meanings.meaning: To Show Someone What One Can Do

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When things are put in a <kanji>row</kanji> they end up forming a <vocabulary>line</vocabulary>. This can be a line of people waiting in a <vocabulary>queue</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>row</vocabulary> of seats in a theater, or a <vocabulary>column</vocabulary> in Excel and other spreadsheets.
When you get someone to <kanji>transmit</kanji> information, they're a type of <vocabulary>intermediary</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>go-between</vocabulary>, if you will.
You've seen how the word 情け means pity, so adding ない to that turns it into an adjective meaning <vocabulary>pitiable</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>miserable</vocabulary>.

Remember 放す (to release) and 放れる (to get loose)? 放つ is another transitive verb of the <kanji>release</kanji> family, but this is a more dynamic kind of releasing, so it means <vocabulary>to fire</vocabulary> off something. 

You can remember this because you usually need つ (two) hands to fire something off properly, whether it's a slingshot or a hit in baseball.

放つ often implies setting something free with force or impact. It's used to describe things like shooting arrows, firing bullets, letting animals loose into the wild, or even strongly emitting something like light or an offensive smell. More figuratively, it can describe the act of releasing something into the world, whether that's a creative work you're unveiling or a hot take you're firing off on social media.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>arrange</kanji>, and the verb version also means <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put in order</vocabulary>. This has to do with putting things in their rightful place, getting affairs in order, or even preparing equipment.

Remember how you learned that 休み means "break?" When you take a break at <kanji>noon</kanji> it's your <vocabulary>lunch break</vocabulary>! Or, if you aren't hungry, it's a <vocabulary>noon break</vocabulary> instead.

If you say something is going to <kanji>clear up</kanji>, you're usually talking about the weather. That makes this <vocabulary>clear weather</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sunny</vocabulary>.

Maybe because of those connotations, 晴れ can also be used to describe special occasions that are usually public. For example, a wedding or a big recital might be called a 晴れの場 (special occasion). Similarly, the special clothing you wear to such events is called 晴れ着 (formal attire).
<kanji>Yesterday</kanji>'s <kanji>year</kanji> was actually <vocabulary>last year</vocabulary>. Today must be New Years then!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 外 means <kanji>outside</kanji>, and the meaning of this verb is somewhat related. It means <vocabulary>to remove</vocabulary> something. Think of it like this — if you remove your watch, you are putting it "outside" of its usual spot (your wrist), right?

Like many verbs ending in す, this verb is transitive. It's used for when you intentionally take something and put it outside of where it's supposed to be — so depending on the context, it can also mean <vocabulary>to exclude</vocabulary> someone, or even <vocabulary>to miss something</vocabulary> (like a target). See how all these meanings relate to the idea of something ending up outside its intended spot?

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Hearing Something For The First Time

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> time something reaches your <kanji>ear</kanji>, it's <vocabulary>something heard for the first time</vocabulary>. If it's never entered your ear before, it's <vocabulary>news</vocabulary> to you!

meanings.meaning: Something Heard For The First Time

meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <kanji>ride</kanji> as a <kanji>guest</kanji> (or a <kanji>customer</kanji>), that makes you a <vocabulary>passenger</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>ride</kanji> a <kanji>horse</kanji>, that's <vocabulary>horseback riding</vocabulary> or, in some parts of the world, simply <vocabulary>horse riding</vocabulary>.

What's the <kanji>reason</kanji> that something <kanji>come</kanji>s into being? Its <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary>, of course. Nothing can come into the world without a <vocabulary>source</vocabulary>, because it's always <vocabulary>coming from</vocabulary> somewhere.

The kanji means <kanji>doubt</kanji>, so this is just that as a verb. So this means <vocabulary>to doubt</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to suspect</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be suspicious of</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>below</kanji>, which is a clue to the direction this movement verb takes: this is <vocabulary>to go down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to descend</vocabulary>. In some cases, this can also mean <vocabulary>to be issued</vocabulary>, mostly in situations where some sort of grant or allowance is issued by an authority.

You might notice that this is similar to 下る (くだる), and you can use either to describe going down a mountain. The difference is that 下る implies a gradual sloping motion, like floating down a stream, whereas you'd say 下りる if you’re jumping out of trees!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>problem</kanji> and this verb means <vocabulary>to question something</vocabulary>. That's because when you want to get to the bottom of a problem, you question things.

問う has a formal, literary sound and tends to carry a sense of raising a meaningful or weighty question. You'll see it in essays, news articles, and philosophical writing when someone is considering deeper issues, like questioning values, society, or something's very existence. It can also just mean <vocabulary>to ask</vocabulary>, but will sound stuffier and more old-fashioned than the standard 聞く.

Remember 受ける (to receive something) and 入れる (to put in)? This just combines those two. You receive something, and put it into your heart. You accept it. So this verb means <vocabulary>to accept something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take in</vocabulary>. 

You can use this verb for all kinds of acceptance, such as accepting an apology, accepting exchange students to your school, etc.

<kanji>Green</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji> is <vocabulary>green tea</vocabulary>.

緑茶 technically refers to all kinds of green tea (i.e., non-oxidized teas). But in everyday Japanese, the word usually means green-colored tea made from leaf infusions, typically sencha.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lick</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to lick</vocabulary>.

舐める also has a slang meaning of <vocabulary>to underestimate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to look down on</vocabulary>. In those cases it'll often be written as ナメる or sometimes なめる. You might see it in manga or hear characters in movies say なめんなよ (don't underestimate me). Think of the slang meaning like this: you'd have to really underestimate someone to think you could just lick them without consequences, right?
